intro: Sida acuta var. madagascariensis, commonly known as the Madagascar cotton plant, is a flowering plant native to Madagascar. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its soft, hairy stems and small, pale green leaves. The plant produces clusters of fluffy, white flowers that resemble cotton, which is a distinctive botanical feature. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, well-drained soils. This species is also valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine in some regions.
